Award.AwardTitle: Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Track Phase II

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This Phase 2 Noyce project is recruiting strong candidates with STEM degrees to become 45 new science or mathematics teachers. It is adapted to the life circumstances of non-traditional candidates: multiple entry points through the year, early and intense experiences in school classrooms, mastery learning, a learning community, and online delivery. It also provides a pathway to teaching for undergraduate Arts and Sciences and Engineering majors by identifying and orienting promising candidates and involving them in the teaching of lower level undergraduate science and math courses and working with middle and high school students in urban school settings. Upon graduation with a STEM degree the undergraduate candidates enter an accelerated teacher licensure program. The project explores new recruitment techniques through Arts and Sciences and Education college collaboration, improves the mentoring and induction experiences, and develops a better understanding of the support needed to retain new teachers. Given the high drop-out rate of new teachers, research into the particular factors involved in their recruitment and retention as well as the continued development of beginning teachers is crucial. So, a major component of the project is to fully involve school districts in the training of teachers of diverse backgrounds in a deep and substantive manner through vigorous, intentional efforts to foster school and university cooperation. This effort explores how schools and universities can and should work together to plan careful induction experiences and create sustaining structures that allow teachers to collaborate in ways that support and nurture communities of practice to enhance the learning and growth of teachers and students

POR.DRECONTENT:
The University of Cincinnati’s Noyce Scholarships and Stipends Phase II project was designed to meet the needs of local schools for highly qualified secondary science and mathematics teachers. This was accomplished by recruiting STEM career changers, recent STEM graduates and dual major undergraduate students in the STEM disciplines. The project recruited and accepted 56 potential STEM teachers. Of the 56 accepted STEM teachers, 33 are currently teaching in high needs school districts; 11 more are will complete the teacher preparation program in the spring of 2018 and begin teaching in a high needs school district in the fall of 2018. Thus, the University of Cincinnati’s Noyce Scholars Program yielded 44 new secondary STEM teachers. Over the life of the project, the Noyce Scholars program increased the number of secondary STEM teachers licensed and entering the classroom from the University of Cincinnati by 46% and of those new teachers, all took jobs in high needs school districts.

In addition to preparing the new teachers, over the life of the project the University created clear pathways for future STEM undergraduates to continue into teaching. One such program was developed with the College of Engineering. The ACCEND education program allows undergraduate engineering majors to complete their engineering BS and a secondary STEM teaching license in five years. ACCEND students also complete the 5 years with 2/3rd of their Masters in Education completed. In a second pathway project, the Education, and Arts and Sciences faculty worked to develop a pathway for Science and Mathematics students to begin their Masters in Education plus teaching license in their senior year. Once these students graduated from their bachelors program, they complete their teaching license and masters degree in a fifth year. Finally, the project was instrumental in the development of a learning assistants pathway for undergraduates in the sciences. The learning assistants program provides sophomores and juniors with an early teaching experience with STEM discipline faculty member. This early teaching experience encouraged interested STEM students to consider a potential teaching career. These three new pathways into secondary STEM teaching were all developed through the cooperation of the STEM disciplinary, engineering, and education faculty who were supported by the Noyce Scholars grant.

Finally, the University Noyce Scholars program enhanced the knowledge base in STEM teacher preparation and education through an active research program with two focal areas.  The first research area included a follow-up study of Noyce graduates which documented their teaching experiences in high needs school.  This research resulted in conference presentations and a manuscript in preparation about Noyce graduates up to 10 years after completing the teacher preparation program. The research documented why people stay or leave teaching; the factors that result in teachers leaving the classroom; and the roles and responsibilities taken on by those who stay in teaching. The second research focus was a longitudinal study of a small group of Noyce Scholars beginning with the ideas and beliefs at the start of their pre-service program through two years of teaching in an urban setting. This research resulted in an up-coming book chapter and two conference presentations to national audiences. This research documented how the Scholars drew upon their personal strengths to counter relative weaknesses, as they learned to be urban STEM teachers.

The University of Cincinnati’s Noyce Scholars program has affected broader society by producing high quality and highly qualified science and mathematics teachers serving children in high needs, particularly urban, schools. In addition, it can serve as an institutional model for developing new and more flexible pathways for STEM undergraduates to transition into teaching careers. And finally, the program has added to the knowledge base in teacher preparation by looking at our program graduates successes and struggles over time.
